awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Next Generation Rigid Rod Polymers through Combined Computation and Experimentation
awd_abstract_narration:
Polymers impact nearly every part of daily life - from the bristles on a toothbrush to the packaging that protects food.  The chemical composition of a polymer dictates its properties including strength, flexibility, recyclability, etc., which define applications.  In this research project, Prof. Pentzer at Case Western Reserve University and Prof. Lambrecht at University of Pittsburgh explore the use of ketenes, a class of under-utilized monomers, for preparing novel polymers with high mechanical strength, and yet high solubility for facile processing.  Computational prediction is integrated with synthesis and characterization to enable cost- and time-efficient discovery of such new polymers.  This multidisciplinary project provides research training to undergraduate and graduate students, preparing the future generation of skilled workforce in science and engineering fields. 

The research team studies the chain growth polymerization of silyl ketenes, (R3Si(H)C=C=O), which form solution processable polymers with variable backbone and side groups that behave as rigid rod polymers (RRPs). Since silyl ketenes can yield three different polymer backbone chemistries as well as mixtures thereof, the challenge addressed in this work is formation of materials with specific structure and rigidity. The Lambrecht group develops computational approaches for predicting the contributions of "synthons" on reaction energetics and polymer properties from first principles; computational prediction informs synthesis performed in Pentzer's laboratory by proposing rational modifications, including solvent polarity and counterion choice.  The Pentzer group evaluates the impact of experimental conditions on polymerization, synthesizes and characterizes new polymers, and closes the feedback loop by generating empirical data to validate and refine computational approaches of Lambrecht. The research activities include 1) identifying the fundamental reactivity patterns of silyl ketenes as relevant to chain growth polymerization, 2) controlling the formation of well-defined oligomers, and 3) preparing each of the new polymer chemistries individually and establishing their properties and applications. Further, Pentzer and Lambrecht offer annually a two-day workshop on how to successfully combine research in computation and experiment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Overview. The overall goal of this project was to develop new polymers from small molecules called silyl ketenes. Polymers impact nearly every part of daily life - from the bristles on a toothbrush to the packaging that protects food.  The chemical composition of a polymer dictates its properties including strength, flexibility, recyclability, etc., which define applications.  Whereas most polymer chains coil up like wet spaghetti, the polymers that are produced from silyl ketenes are expected to have rigid, linear structures, more like dry spaghetti. Such a difference would result in dramatically different properties. To address the challenge of making these novel polymers, this proposal supported the combination of computational and experimental approaches. Prof. Lambrecht and his group used computation to investigate reactions of silyl ketenes with different initiators with the aim to rationalize reactivity trends. In complement, Prof. Pentzer and her group focused on synthesizing different silyl ketenes and studying their reaction with initiators and the ability to make polymers from them. It was revealed that depending on the initiator used, silyl ketenes can undergo the expected reaction as an electrophile, or they can serve as an acid, with the reaction pathway correlated to the pKa of the initiator. Further, it was revealed that the reactions can propagate, but only lead to the formation of oligomers rather than polymers and that competing reaction pathways led to a combination of produces. This is attributed to the steric hindrance around the propagating chain end; in short, the properties that support the formation of the rigid polymers make it difficult for the polymers to form.

Intellectual Merit. This work provided fundamental scientific insights into how silyl ketenes, a relatively underexplored class of molecules, react with different initiators and the ability to form polymers from these small molecules. Theory and synthesis synergistically combined to advance polymer discovery by 1) developing computational approaches to guide rational synthesis by identifying desirable chemical modifications directly from first principles, and 2) leveraging theoretical predictions to identify promising monomers and developing synthetic strategies to design materials by controlling regioselectivity of polymerization. The work also highlighted the importance of computationally evaluating both the kinetic and thermodynamic considerations of a reaction pathway, as both can inform experimental work.

Broader Impacts. Production of new rigid, extended polymers offers opportunities to develop materials for both unique applications (not possible with current polymers) and also to replace currently used polymers with those that are better performing or more sustainable. This work produced a fruitful collaboration between a computational chemist and a polymer chemist, who collectively supported the research and career development of undergraduate and graduate students. A total of 4 PhD students and 6 undergraduate students were partially supported, many of whom have graduated and are now part of the American STEM workforce. These students were trained in both experiment and computation, in addition to skills required for collaboration and interdisciplinary research and “softer” skills of professional development. The PIs also developed and ran workshop on best practices and benefits of collaboration across experiment and computation.


Last Modified: 03/16/2022
Modified by: Emily B Pentzer
